basics.name: Hannu Hartikainen
basics.label: Twin father, hacker, occasional full stack developer
basics.summary:
I'm a twin father who loves learning and seeing his own handiwork. This is why I love hacking, too.

I want to do new, interesting things (that is, new to me; I wouldn't mind developing device drivers in C). The realistic way to do that, I believe, is to write high-quality, readable and maintainable code. That way I don't have to go back to fix it---as often, at least.

My dream is to become a true full stack developer: to understand and be able to implement all the layers of the technology that modern applications run on. Say, a web application needs the browser which depends on OpenGL and the TCP/IP stack and the scheduler and the filesystem and eventually the CPU microcode. Obviously really learning all this is not possible in a year or even a decade, but perhaps in a lifetime...

Besides hacking, I highly value my free time and my family. Switching to a four-day, 30-hour work week has been great and I'm not planning to switch back.

work.summary:
At HiQ I've become a software development generalist, working mostly on web frontend and backend, but on occasion also continuos integration and test automation, deployment, and even database administration and UI design. Colleagues often come to me with all kinds of (technical) questions, probably not because I know a lot but because I love learning and helping others.

One of my greatest achievements at HiQ was coming up with an optimization that brought the runtime of a performance-heavy business-critical piece of PL/SQL down by over 50%, after two other senior developers had decided it could not be optimized further. In some cases this meant over five minutes of time saved, which apparently corresponded to a lot of money.

Highlights from my work on public websites includes implementing http://nordpoolspot.com/ and http://orion.fi/ (in teams of 2 developers, a designer and others).

work.company: Aalto University, Department of Media Technology
work.summary:
I conducted research and wrote my thesis, Real-time Human Body Reconstruction Using a Depth Camera.

The thesis taught me a lot about scientific research, open-ended problem solving and practical graphics programming.

I worked on tools for internal use in software projects, e.g. Trac plugins for project management.

Patria was my first job involving programming, and I learned a lot about software engineering, many different technologies and especially information security.
